title: I received a call from a Ray Walton stating that I was being sued and that I needed to call him back at once to clear this up
question: I received a call from a person named Ray Walton from a place called (Keyek Scholers) and this Ray person tells me that I took a payday loan from a place call 10 payday loan for the amount of $220.00 which is not up to $350.00. i explained to this Ray person that I did not take a payday loan and that this must be a mistake and how do clear this up. This Ray person stated to me that yes you did take out this loan and you must pay today. I asked to speak to his supervisor which a Andy Foster got on the phone and stated to me that I need to pay them $350.00 today. I explained to Andy Foster that I did not take out this payday loan and how do I clear my name. Andy stated that he could not provided with that information and that I would need to pay today.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit repair,Credit score,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Criminal charges for identity theft,Police interrogation,Privacy law,Credit card fraud,Consumer protection,Small claims court,Personal information
answers:
You just learned that you are the victim of identity theft and you need to review my legal guide on Avvo (go through my Avvo profile to access this legal guide for free). The guide will walk you through each step that you need to take to protect yourself and determine if there is anything else, by getting your credit reports for free, since if this person did it once, they likely did it more and your credit is probably badly damaged from it. You can restore your own credit better than any credit repair company.

Also, you will need a police report and an FTC Identity Theft Complaint, which is also explained in my Avvo legal guide, so that you can dispute this debt with the debt collector or payday lender. I would be careful about not sending them your private information on the FTC complaint, because payday lenders and their debt collectors are particularly aggressive and may simply take all the personal information that you have "given them" and use it to harm you further.

You may ultimately need to hire an experienced consumer credit attorney to help you resolve any disputes or violations of your rights that remain with this company or the credit reporting agencies.

There's a law NY firm called Kaye Scholer, but they're a big and reputable firm and I can't imagine anyone from that firm acting as you've described, which sounds like fear-mongering and a shakedown.

No one sues anyone for a couple hundred dollars, and if they did, they wouldn't use a lawyer, because it wouldn' be cost effective and you can't be represented by lawyers in Small Claims court anyway.

I'd ignore this.
